byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Nicole Perlroth from San Francisco.
byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH

abstract: American officials and private security firms say they have observed surge in sophisticated computer espionage by Iran in months following historic nuclear accord, culminating in series of cyberattacks against State Dept; experts say Iranian hard-liners may be leveraging attacks to gain power nuclear program would have otherwise provided.
lead_paragraph: American officials say cyberespionage is becoming a tool to obtain the influence that many in Iran hoped the nuclear program would give the country.

headline.main: Iranian Hackers Attack State Dept. via Social Media Accounts
headline.print_headline: Iran Hones Cyberattacks on U.S. After Nuclear Deal

snippet: American officials say cyberespionage is becoming a tool to obtain the influence that many in Iran hoped the nuclear program would give the country.
